questions.text: All of the following pelvic structures support the vagina, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation: D Supports of vagina : DeLancey introduced three level system of support Level I—Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments support theuterus and vaginal vault. The cervix remains at or just above the ischial spines, and the vagina lies horizontally. Level II—Pelvic fascias and paracolpos which connects the vagina to the white line on the lateral pelvic wall through the arcus tendineus. This includes the pubocervical fascia anteriorly and the rectovaginal fascia and septum posteriorly. Level III—Levator ani muscle supports the lower onethird of the vagina. The levator muscle forms a platform against which the pelvic organs (uterus and upper vagina) gets compressed during straining. Perineal body includes levator ani muscles , bulbospongisus, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles , external anal and urethral spincters all of which are included in supports of uterus. Hence answer here is option D which is not included in supports of uterus

questions.text: All are related to lateral vaginal fornix except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The lateral relations from below upwards are The cavernous tissue of the vestibule; The superficial muscles of the perineum; The triangular ligament and at about 2.5 cm from the introitus the levator ani, lateral to which is the ischiorectal fossa. Above the levator lies the endopelvic cellular tissue, and its condensation, called Mackenrodt’s ligament, on either side. The ureter traverses this tissue in the ureteric canal and is about 12 mm anterolateral to the lateral fornix. The vaginal branch of the uterine artery arises before the uterine artery passes vertically upward at the level of the internal os. It passes downwards through the parametrium to reach the vagina in the region of the lateral fornix. Inferior vesicular artery is not included in relations of lateral vaginal fornix hence answer here is option C

questions.text: The pH of vagina in adults is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 3.5–4.5. Correct Response: pH of vagina in adults (A) In adult females, the normal vaginal pH ranges from 3.5 to 4.5, making it slightly acidic. This acidity is primarily due to the presence of Lactobacillus bacteria, which produce lactic acid by metabolizing glycogen secreted by the vaginal epithelial cells. The acidic environment plays a crucial role in preventing the growth of pathogenic organisms, thereby maintaining vaginal health and reducing the risk of infections like bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted infections. Incorrect Responses: B. 4.5–5.5 While slightly higher than the normal range, a pH of 4.5–5.5 is not typical for a healthy adult vagina. Such a pH may indicate a deviation from normal physiology and could suggest conditions like bacterial vaginosis or other infections that disrupt the balance of vaginal flora. C. 5.5–6.5 A pH range of 5.5–6.5 is considered alkaline for the vaginal environment. This level is more commonly observed in postmenopausal women, where reduced estrogen levels lead to decreased glycogen production, disrupting the acidic environment. It is not characteristic of healthy adult vaginal physiology. D. 6.5–7.5 A vaginal pH of 6.5–7.5 is significantly alkaline and highly abnormal in adult females. This pH range may be associated with infections, amniotic fluid leakage during pregnancy, or other pathological conditions requiring medical evaluation.

questions.text: Protective bacterium in normal vagina is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The vaginal secretion is small in amount in healthy women and consists of white coagulated material. When it is examined under the microscope, squamous cells which have been shed from the vaginal epithelium and Döderlein’s bacilli alone are found. Döderlein’s bacillus (lactobacilli) is a large Grampositive rod-shaped organism, which grows anaerobically on acid media. The vaginal secretion is acidic due to the presence of lactic acid, and this acidity inhibits the growth of pathogenic organisms. They also produce hydrogen peroxide which is toxic to anaerobes. Other flora of vagina are: Facultative organisms (low, non-pathogenic numbers) are :Diphtheroids, Coagulase negative staphylococc, Streptococci (groups B and D, E. coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, Mycoplasma hominis Anaerobic organisms (poor concentration)are: Peptostreptococci, Bacteroides and Fusobacterium species Among all these organism only lactobaciili are protective bacteria found in normal vagina

questions.text: The main source of physiological secretion found in the vagina is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The components of vaginal secretion are from the following: The sweat and sebaceous glands of the vulva and the specialized racemose glands of Bartholin’s. The characteristic odour of vaginal secretion is provided by the apocrine glands of the vulva. The transudate of the vaginal epithelium and the desquamated cells of the cornified layer. This is strongly acidic. The mucous secretion of the endocervical glands which is alkaline. n The endometrial glandular secretion. All these play a varying part at different times of the menstrual cycle, the last two being most active just before menstruation. Hence the main source is cervical glands

questions.text: Uterine-cervix ratio upto 10 years of age:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 1:2. Correct Response: Uterine-cervix ratio in children (D) In females up to 10 years of age, the uterus-to-cervix ratio is 1:2, meaning the cervix is twice as long as the uterine body during this stage of development. This is due to the underdeveloped uterine body and the relatively larger size of the cervix. Hormonal influence, primarily estrogen, is minimal during this prepubertal phase, leading to the immature size and structure of the uterus. As puberty approaches and hormonal stimulation increases, the uterine body begins to grow in proportion to the cervix. Incorrect Responses: A. 3:2 A ratio of 3:2 is not typical for the uterine-cervix relationship in children. This ratio is closer to what is observed in the postpubertal or adult female when the uterine body becomes larger under the influence of hormones like estrogen and progesterone. B. 2:1 A ratio of 2:1 represents the uterine-cervix proportion seen in adult females, where the uterine body is twice the size of the cervix due to the effect of reproductive hormones during puberty and adulthood. This is not applicable to prepubertal females. C. 3:1 A ratio of 3:1 is also incorrect for the prepubertal phase. Such a proportion may be seen in pregnancy or specific pathological conditions where the uterine body becomes significantly larger than the cervix. This is not typical for children.

questions.text: The epithelial lining of cervical canal is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) High columnar. Correct Response: High columnar (B) The epithelial lining of the cervical canal is composed of high columnar epithelium, specifically a single layer of tall, mucus-secreting columnar cells. This specialized epithelium lines the endocervix, the canal that connects the uterine cavity to the vaginal cavity. The mucus produced by these cells plays a vital role in fertility, forming a protective barrier against pathogens and facilitating or inhibiting sperm passage depending on the phase of the menstrual cycle. The presence of high columnar epithelium in this region ensures efficient secretion and optimal interaction with the surrounding tissues. Incorrect Responses: A. Low columnar Low columnar epithelium is not found in the cervical canal. The cells lining the cervical canal are tall and mucus-secreting, making "low columnar" an inaccurate descriptor for this anatomical site. C. Stratified squamous Stratified squamous epithelium lines the ectocervix (the portion of the cervix that protrudes into the vagina) and the vaginal canal. This type of epithelium is well-suited for areas subject to friction and wear, but it does not line the cervical canal. D. Ciliated columnar Ciliated columnar epithelium is found in the fallopian tubes, where it aids in the transport of the ovum towards the uterus. While the cervical canal contains columnar cells, they are not ciliated. Instead, they are specialized for mucus secretion.

questions.text: Nabothian follicles occur in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chronic cervicitis often manifests clinically as an erosion or as a Nabothian follicle. The cervical erosion results from the extension of the columnar endocervical epithelium beyond the external cervical os to replace the squamous epithelium covering the portio vaginalis of the cervix. Whenever the mouth of an endocervical gland opening gets blocked, it gets distended with inspissated secretion—resulting in a cystic bulge known as the Nabothian follicle

choices.text: A groove between labia minora and hymen

questions.text: Bartholin’s duct opens into:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A groove between labia minora and hymen The Bartholin's ducts (also known as the greater vestibular glands' ducts) open into the posterolateral aspect of the vaginal introitus, specifically in the groove between the labia minora and the hymenal ring, at approximately the 4 o’clock and 8 o’clock positions. Explanation of incorrect options: A. Labia majora and minora – Incorrect, because the ducts do not open on the labia themselves but rather in the vestibule between the labia minora and hymen. C. The lower vagina – Incorrect, as the ducts do not open into the vaginal canal itself but rather outside the vaginal opening, in the vestibule. D. The upper vagina – Incorrect, the Bartholin's ducts are located near the external genitalia, not in the upper vagina.

questions.text: A woman presents with a fluctuant non tender swelling at the introitus. The best treatment is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) When duct of bartholins gland is blocked it is known as bartholin’s cyst. It is present in posterolateral wall of vagina. It can be differentiated from Gartner’s duct cyst which is present in Anterolateral wall of vagina If the cyst is asymptomatic no treatment is required while in symptomatic cases treatment of choice is Marsupilisation If the age of person is >40yrs then excision of cyst should be done as beyond thid age bartholins cancer can occur If the swelling is tender then mostly it is bartholins abscess- treatment of chooce in such cases is incision and drainage. Most common organism causing abscess is E.coli and gonorrhoea.

questions.text: Narrowest part of fallopian tube is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The fallopian tube measures 4 inch (10 cm) or more in length and approximately 8 mm in diameter, but the diameter diminishes near the cornu of the uterus to 1 mm. The fallopian tube is divided anatomically into four parts: The interstitial portion is the innermost part of the tube which traverses the myometrium to open into the endometrial cavity. It is the shortest and narrowest part of the tube measuring 2cm in length and 0.7mm in diameter The isthmus part mesures 3cm in length and 1mm in diameter The ampula being the widest part mesures 5cm in length and 6mm in diameter While the fimbriated extremity or infundibulum is where the abdominal ostium opens into the peritoneal cavity. Hence answer here is option A

questions.text: ‘Peg cells’ are seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The epithelium of the mucous membrane consists of three types of cells: The most common is ciliated, and is either columnar or cubical in type. Its function is to propel a fluid current towards the uterus and plays some part in the transport of the inert ovum which, unlike the sperm, has no motile power of its own. Next in order of frequency is a goblet-shaped cell, not ciliated, which does not give the histochemical reactions for mucin. Its function is lubricant and possibly nutritive to the ovum. A cell intermediate in type to the two already mentioned can be distinguished, and small rod-shaped cells are also present. These are the so-called peg cells whose purpose is not known. It is resting cells of fallopian tube

questions.text: The length of fallopian tube is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 10–12 cm. Correct Response: Length of fallopian tube (B) The fallopian tube, or uterine tube, is approximately 10–12 cm in length. This structure plays a critical role in female reproduction by providing a passage for the ovum to travel from the ovary to the uterus. The fallopian tube is divided into four sections: Interstitial portion – the narrowest segment within the uterine wall. Isthmus – a slightly wider portion connecting the interstitial segment to the ampulla. Ampulla – the widest and longest part where fertilization usually occurs. Infundibulum – the funnel-shaped distal end with fimbriae that capture the ovum during ovulation. This 10–12 cm length is optimal for supporting ovum transport, fertilization, and early embryonic development before implantation in the uterus. Incorrect Responses: A. 8–10 cm While this range is close, it underestimates the typical length of the fallopian tube. A shorter tube might not provide sufficient length for normal ovum transport and fertilization processes. C. 15–18 cm This length is too long and does not align with the anatomy of the human female reproductive system. Such an overestimation may stem from confusion with structures in other species or a misunderstanding of measurements. D. 18–20 cm This length is significantly larger than the actual measurement of the fallopian tube and is not anatomically correct for humans. Such dimensions are excessive and not observed in normal female anatomy.

questions.text: Vaginal epithelium is derived from:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The vagina is developed from the following sources: Upper 4/5th, above the hymen—the mucous membrane is derived from endoderm of the canalized sinovaginal bulbs. The musculature is developed from the mesoderm of two fused Müllerian ducts. Lower 1/5th, below the hymen is developed from the endoderm of the urogenital sinus. External vaginal orifice is formed from the genital fold ectoderm after rupture of the urogenital membrane.

questions.text: Anatomical sphincter of fallopian tubes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The isthmus comprises the next and inner part of the tube and represents about one-third of the total length, i.e. 35 mm. It is narrow but a little wider than the interstitial part and its lumen has a diameter of 2 mm. Its muscle wall contains both longitudinal and circular fibres hence act as anatomical sphincter of fallopian tube and it is covered by peritoneum except for a small inferior bare area related to the broad ligament. It is relatively straight.

choices.text: Is homologus to scrotum in males
Is supplied by branches of internal and external pudendal arteries
Drains into superficial inguinal lymph nodes
The broad ligament terminates at its anterior end

questions.text: With regards to labia majora all are correct except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Labia majora It is homologus to scrotum in males Drains into superficial inguinal lymph nodes, while labia minora into deep inguinal Ln The labia majora pass from the mons veneris to end posteriorly in the skin over the perineal body. The blood vessels of the perineum and external genitalia are derived from the internal pudendal artery, a terminal branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery and its anasthomosis with Branches of femoral artery—superficial and deep external pudendal Round ligament starts from upper end of uterus goes into deep inguinal ring passing via inguinal canal and into superficial inguinal ring finally terminates into labia majora

choices.text: Is attached to the posterior layer of the broad ligament by mesovarium
Has hilus cells in the cortex
Left Ovarian veins drain into inferior vena cava
Is connected to the uterus by infundibulopelvic ligament

questions.text: Ovary is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The ovary is attached to the posterior layer of the broad ligament by the mesovarium, to the lateral pelvic wall by the infundibulopelvic ligament and to the uterus by the ovarian ligament. Cortex consist of stromal cells which are thickened beneath the germinal epithelium to form tunica albuginea. During reproductive period (i.e., from puberty to menopause) the cortex is studded with numerous follicular structures, called the functional units of the ovary, in various phases of their development. The structures include primordial follicles, maturing follicles, Graafian follicles and corpus luteum. Medulla consists of loose connective tissues, few unstriped muscles, blood vessels and nerves. There is a small collection of cells called “hilus cells” which are homologous to the interstitial cells of the testes. Arterial supply is from the ovarian artery, a branch of the abdominal aorta. Venous drainage is through pampiniform plexus, to form the ovarian veins which drain into inferior vena cava on the right side and left renal vein on the left side Hence answer here is option A

choices.text: Is lined entirely by ciliated columnar epithelium
Surrounded by peritoneum on all sides except along the line of attachment of mesosalpinx

questions.text: The fallopian tube:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fallopian tube consists of three layers— Serous: consists of peritoneum on all sides except along the line of attachment of mesosalpinx, Muscular: arranged in two layers outer longitudinal and inner circular, Mucous membrane has three different cell types and is thrown into longitudinal folds. The epithelium rests on a delicate vascular reticulum of connective tissue Mucous membrane is lined by: Columnar ciliated epithelial cells that are most predominant near the ovarian end of the tube. These cells compose 25% of the mucosal cells, Secretory columnar cells are present at the isthmic segment and compose 60% of epithelial cells, Peg cells are found in between the above two cells. They are the variant of secretory cells. Fallopian tube doesn’t undergo shedding during menstrual cycle

choices.text: Is homologous to GUBERNACULUM of testes
It is supplied by uterine artery

questions.text: All are true about the round ligament except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The round ligament of the uterus is fibro-muscular connective tissue.It is largely fibrous but has some smooth muscle fibres medially (from the uterus) and some striated fibres laterally (from the internal oblique and transversalis muscles). From the cornu of the uterus, the round ligament crosses the pelvis through the deep inguinal ring which then traverses the inguinal canal and then enters the labia majora, where it terminates with its fibers blending into the mons pubis. Each round ligament is about 10 to 12 centimeters long. The round ligament of the uterus develops from the gubernaculum. The round ligament receives blood from Sampson's artery which is a branch of uterine artery

questions.text: The most important indication for surgical repair of a bicornuate uterus is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Habitual abortion. Correct Response: Surgical repair of a bicornuate uterus in habitual abortion (D) The most important indication for the surgical repair of a bicornuate uterus is habitual abortion (recurrent miscarriages). A bicornuate uterus is a congenital uterine anomaly where the uterus has two cavities instead of one, leading to a risk of pregnancy complications, including early pregnancy loss. Surgical repair, typically through a procedure like metroplasty, can improve pregnancy outcomes by correcting the anatomical abnormalities that may interfere with embryo implantation and early pregnancy development. This procedure is often recommended when a bicornuate uterus is identified as a contributing factor to recurrent miscarriages. Incorrect Responses: A. Infertility While a bicornuate uterus can be associated with infertility, this is not the most common indication for surgical repair. Many women with this uterine anomaly can conceive and carry pregnancies to term, although they may experience higher risks of complications. The surgical correction is usually more focused on habitual abortion rather than infertility, unless other factors are involved. B. Dysmenorrhoea Dysmenorrhoea (painful menstruation) is not a primary reason for surgical repair of a bicornuate uterus. While uterine anomalies can contribute to menstrual discomfort, the more pressing concerns leading to surgery are related to pregnancy outcomes, such as recurrent miscarriages (habitual abortion), rather than pain management. Dysmenorrhoea can often be managed with medical therapies or conservative approaches. C. Menorrhagia Menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding) is not a major indication for surgical correction of a bicornuate uterus. Although a bicornuate uterus may potentially contribute to abnormal bleeding patterns, it is not typically addressed surgically unless there are specific complications related to pregnancy or miscarriage. Menorrhagia can often be treated through less invasive methods, such as hormonal therapy or dilation and curettage (D&C).

questions.text: Vaginal atresia is associated with :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The lower ends of the Müllerian ducts terminate in the urogenital sinus, into the posterior part of which they project as a solid Müllerian tubercle. Around this Müllerian tubercle, there is a solid proliferation of the urogenital sinus on each side, called the sinovaginal bulbs. By canalization of the sinovaginal bulbs, the lower quarter to one-third of the vagina is formed The vagina is therefore developed in its upper threequarters from the fused Müllerian ducts The vertical fusion between the Müllerian systems and the sinovaginal bulb results in the formation of the vaginal canal. The uterus fallopian tube and most of the vagina is derived from mullerian duct. Hence both uterus and part of vagina develops from ,mullerian system so vaginal atresia is associated with yterine atresia

questions.text: Ideal age for repair of vaginal agenesis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Before marriage. Correct Response: Repair of vaginal agenesis before marriage (D) The ideal time for the repair of vaginal agenesis is generally before marriage, typically in the late teens or early twenties. The reason for performing surgical reconstruction (vaginoplasty) before marriage is to enable the individual to have normal sexual function and to improve quality of life. Early intervention also allows for proper psychological and emotional development, addressing concerns related to intimacy and sexual relationships. Repair is usually done after the individual reaches an appropriate age for surgery, when growth has stabilized, but before any marital concerns arise. Incorrect Responses: A. 6 months Performing vaginal agenesis repair at 6 months is not appropriate, as the child’s physical and psychological development is not at the stage where surgical intervention would be beneficial or feasible. At this age, the child is still developing, and the anatomical structures are not fully matured, so surgery would not be advisable. B. 3 years Repairing vaginal agenesis at 3 years is also premature, as the child is still in early stages of growth and development. At this age, the child has not reached puberty, and the vaginal structures have not yet developed sufficiently to allow for effective surgical intervention. C. At puberty While puberty marks the onset of physical and sexual maturity, repairing vaginal agenesis at puberty can be delayed. It is generally more beneficial to perform the surgery earlier, before the individual enters into adult relationships or marriage, to allow for a smoother transition into adulthood and ensure better sexual health and psychological well-being.

questions.text: Ovary develop from :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ovary starts to develop by the fifth week. The ovarian differentiation is determined by the presence of a determinant located on the gene of the short arm of X-sex chromosome though the autosomes are also involved in the ovarian development. Two intact sex chromosomes (XX) are necessary for the development of the ovaries. The genital ridge extends from the pronephric region above to the sacral region below and, in its earliest form, is represented by an elongated vertical prominence. Genital ridge results in development of ovary

questions.text: Diagnosis of septate uterus done by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diagnosis of septate uterus Combined hysteroscopy and laparoscopy help to differentiate between bicornuate uterus and septate uterus.The presence of the uterine fundus suggests a septate uterus. Ultrasonography—septate uterus appears as two cavities without sagittal notching and the intercornual distance ,4.0 cm. Diagnosis of bicornuate uterus is favoured, if the fundal midpoint indentation is .5 mm above the inter-ostial line. Hysterosalpingography (HSG)—cannot reliably differentiate between septate and a bicornuate/arcuate uterus. If the angle of divergence between the two uterine cavities is 75°, the defect is most likely to be septate uterus. If the angle of divergence is not 75° but 105° , a diagnosis cannot be made. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)—it is an accurate and noninvasive investigation to make a diagnosis of septate uterus. If the septum extends to 30% of the septal cavity, surgical resection is indicated.

questions.text: MC congenital abnormality of uterus is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Unicornuate uterus accounts for 1–2% of all uterovaginal anomalies and is often associated with a poor reproductive performance. While bicornuate uterus is present in 25% of cases Septate uterus is most common. It is associated with higher incidence of pregnancy wastage About 25% incsidence of spontaneous first trimester abortions, 6% second trimester abortions.

questions.text: Complete failure of mullerian duct fusion will result in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A symmetric lateral fusion defect results in each Müllerian duct developing independently side by side without communication leading to the formation of double uterus. Each duct forms one cervix, one uterus and one fallopian tube on either side. The duplication may go right down the vagina (part derived from Müllerian ducts) as well. Such complete duplication of the uterus is often referred to as ‘uterus didelphys’

questions.text: Bicornuate uterus is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Incomplete fusion of paramesonephric duct. Correct Response: Incomplete fusion of paramesonephric duct (B) A bicornuate uterus results from the incomplete fusion of the paramesonephric ducts (also known as Müllerian ducts) during embryonic development. Normally, the two Müllerian ducts fuse to form a single, centrally located uterine cavity. When this fusion process is incomplete, the result is a heart-shaped uterus with two distinct cavities, known as a bicornuate uterus. This anomaly can lead to reproductive complications such as miscarriage, preterm birth, and abnormal fetal positioning, although many women with this condition can still conceive. Incorrect Responses: A. Incomplete fusion of uterine cavity While the condition of a bicornuate uterus involves an incomplete fusion, the exact mechanism involves the Müllerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) rather than the uterine cavity itself. The cavity itself forms due to the incomplete fusion of the two ducts, so this option is too broad and not entirely accurate in describing the cause. C. Incomplete fusion of mesonephric duct The mesonephric ducts (also known as Wolffian ducts) are involved in the formation of male reproductive structures, such as the epididymis, vas deferens, and seminal vesicles. They do not contribute to the development of the uterus or its anomalies. The uterine malformations, such as a bicornuate uterus, are related to the Müllerian ducts, not the mesonephric ducts. D. Incomplete formation of vagina The vagina forms from the sinovaginal bulbs, which arise from the urogenital sinus. The malformation of the vagina does not directly cause a bicornuate uterus, although uterine and vaginal malformations can occur together in certain conditions. The primary issue in a bicornuate uterus is the failure of the Müllerian ducts to fuse, not the formation of the vagina.

choices.text: Two uterine cavity with one cervix

questions.text: Unicollis bicornis means:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Two uterine cavities with one cervix. Correct Response: Two uterine cavities with one cervix (A) Unicollis bicornis refers to a congenital uterine anomaly where there are two uterine cavities (as in a bicornuate uterus) but only one cervix. In this condition, the two Müllerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) fail to fully fuse, resulting in a heart-shaped uterus with two cavities, but the cervix remains single. This anomaly can be associated with reproductive complications, but the key feature is the presence of two uterine cavities and one cervix, distinguishing it from other uterine abnormalities. Incorrect Responses: B. Single vagina with double uterus This option refers to a uterus didelphys or a double uterus, which is a condition where there are two distinct uterine cavities, two cervices, and one or two vaginas. Unicollis bicornis specifically involves a single cervix, not a double uterus, making this option incorrect. C. Incomplete septum of uterus An incomplete septum refers to a septate uterus, where there is a partial septum within a single uterine cavity. This condition differs from a bicornuate uterus, where there are two separate cavities. The term "unicollis bicornis" does not describe an incomplete septum, making this option incorrect. D. Double uterus and double cervix A double uterus and double cervix is a description of uterus didelphys, a condition where there are two completely separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix. Unicollis bicornis only involves one cervix, so this option does not apply.

choices.text: Epoophron and caudal end of wolffian duct

questions.text: All of the following structures are analogus except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Epophoron and caudal end of Wolffian duct. Correct Response: Epophoron and caudal end of Wolffian duct (C) The epophoron is a vestigial structure in females, derived from the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct. It is often considered the vestige of the male epididymis. However, it does not serve an analogous function to any male structure in a direct sense. The caudal end of the Wolffian duct in males develops into the epididymis, a part of the male reproductive system. While both structures originate from the Wolffian duct, their functions in male and female reproductive systems differ, and they are not considered analogous structures in the same way other male and female structures are. Therefore, this is the correct answer, as the epophoron and caudal end of the Wolffian duct do not share analogous functions or roles in the reproductive systems. Incorrect Responses: A. Labia majora and scrotum (A) The labia majora in females and the scrotum in males are analogous structures because both originate from the same embryonic tissue (the labioscrotal swellings). In males, the labioscrotal swellings develop into the scrotum, while in females, they develop into the labia majora. Both structures serve similar protective functions for their respective reproductive organs, making them analogous. B. Labia minora and penile urethra (B) The labia minora and the penile urethra are also considered analogous structures. The labia minora in females and the penile urethra in males develop from the urethral folds in the embryo. Both structures are involved in the genitalia and serve as openings to their respective reproductive systems (vaginal opening and urethral opening), making them analogous. D. Clitoris and glans penis (D) The clitoris in females and the glans penis in males are analogous structures as they both develop from the genital tubercle during embryonic development. Both serve as the primary erectile tissue in their respective genders and play key roles in sexual arousal, making them analogous in function and structure.

questions.text: All are derivatives of paramesonephirc duct except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gartner's duct. Correct Response: Gartner's duct (D) Gartner's duct is not a derivative of the paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct. It is actually a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females. During embryonic development, the mesonephric duct develops into male reproductive structures such as the epididymis and vas deferens, but in females, parts of this duct can persist as Gartner's duct. These ducts can be found along the lateral aspects of the vagina and may sometimes form cysts. Therefore, Gartner's duct does not arise from the paramesonephric duct and is the correct exception in this list. Incorrect Responses: A. Appendix of testis (A) The appendix of the testis is a small vestigial structure derived from the paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct in males. During fetal development, parts of the paramesonephric duct regress in males, but some remnants remain, which can form the appendix of the testis. This structure is an example of a paramesonephric duct derivative. B. Fallopian tube (B) The fallopian tubes are direct derivatives of the paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts. In females, the paramesonephric ducts fuse to form the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper part of the vagina. Thus, the fallopian tubes are a key structure derived from the paramesonephric ducts. C. Uterus (C) The uterus is also a derivative of the paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts. The fusion of the two paramesonephric ducts forms the uterine cavity, and the ducts also contribute to the formation of the cervix and the upper part of the vagina in females.

questions.text: The triangular area bounded by fourchette and labia minora is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vestibule. Correct Response: Vestibule (C) The vestibule is the triangular area of the vulva that is bounded by the labia minora and the fourchette. It is the area between the labia minora and extends to the vaginal opening, including the urethral opening. The vestibule contains structures such as the vaginal introitus, the external urethral meatus, and the openings of the Bartholin's glands. This area is crucial for sexual and reproductive health, making it the correct answer to this question. Incorrect Responses: A. Fossa navicularis (A) The fossa navicularis is a shallow, bowl-shaped area located at the posterior part of the vaginal introitus, near the junction of the labia minora. It is not the triangular area described in the question, which is the vestibule. The fossa navicularis is located within the vestibule, but it is a specific part of it, not the entire area. B. Fourchette (B) The fourchette is the area at the posterior end of the vulva where the labia majora meet, at the bottom of the vaginal opening. It is not a triangular area, but rather a structure that marks the transition between the vulva and perineum. Thus, it does not correspond to the area described in the question. D. Vulva (D) The vulva is the external female genitalia, which includes the labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, vestibule, and fourchette. The vulva as a whole encompasses a much larger area than just the triangular space bounded by the labia minora and fourchette, which is specifically the vestibule.

questions.text: Prostate glands is homologous to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Skene glands. Correct Response: Skene glands (C) The Skene glands, also known as the paraurethral glands, are homologous to the prostate gland in males. Both structures develop from the urethral embryonic tissue and are involved in the secretion of fluids. The prostate gland in males produces a significant portion of the fluid in semen, while the Skene glands in females secrete a fluid that is thought to contribute to lubrication and may play a role in sexual response. Because of their embryonic origin and function, the Skene glands are considered the female homologs of the male prostate. Incorrect Responses: A. Bartholin's gland (A) The Bartholin's glands are not homologous to the prostate. These glands are found in females and are responsible for secreting mucus to lubricate the vagina during sexual arousal. They develop from the labioscrotal folds and are not derived from the same embryonic tissue as the prostate gland, which makes them anatomically and functionally distinct from the prostate. B. Cowper's gland (B) The Cowper's glands, also known as bulbourethral glands, are located in males and secrete a clear fluid that lubricates the urethra during sexual arousal. While they serve a similar function to the Bartholin's glands in females, their embryological origin is different from that of the prostate, making them not homologous to it. D. Bulbourethral glands (D) The bulbourethral glands (Cowper's glands) are also not homologous to the prostate. They are part of the male reproductive system and are responsible for secreting a lubricating fluid that helps neutralize the acidity of urine in the urethra. While they are similar in function to the Bartholin's glands in females, they are not homologous to the prostate in terms of embryonic origin or structure.

questions.text: Vaginal defence is lost:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) After 10 days of birth. Correct Response: After 10 days of birth (B) The vaginal defense is typically lost after 10 days of birth because the newborn’s vaginal flora, which provides protection from infections, is initially underdeveloped. In the early days of life, the newborn’s immune system is still maturing, and the vagina may lack the normal acidic environment provided by estrogen in later life. However, within the first 10 days after birth, the initial microbial protection (often transferred from the mother's microbiota) is still being established. Once this phase passes, the vaginal environment becomes more susceptible to infections until the child reaches puberty when hormonal changes begin to establish a more protective vaginal flora. Incorrect Responses: A. Within 10 days of birth (A) This option is incorrect because the vaginal defense is not lost within the first 10 days of life. During this time, the vaginal flora is still undergoing establishment, but defense mechanisms are not yet fully lost. The protection gradually diminishes after 10 days as the initial microbiological and immune defenses evolve. C. During pregnancy (C) This option is incorrect because during pregnancy, the vaginal environment is influenced by increased levels of estrogen, which help to maintain an acidic pH and provide some defense against infections. Vaginal defense is not lost during pregnancy; in fact, hormonal changes provide a protective barrier. However, certain infections may still pose risks during this time due to altered immunity, but this is different from the total loss of defense described in the question. D. At puberty (D) This option is incorrect because, at puberty, hormonal changes actually enhance vaginal defense rather than cause its loss. Puberty marks the development of a fully functional vaginal microbiota and a more acidic vaginal environment, thanks to the increase in estrogen production. Therefore, vaginal defense is strengthened, not lost, at this stage.

questions.text: Angle of anteflexion occurs at the level of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Internal os. Correct Response: Internal os (B) The angle of anteflexion of the uterus refers to the forward bend of the uterus at the level of the internal os. The internal os is the opening between the cervix and the uterine body, and it is where the uterus bends forward in a typical anteflexed position. The angle formed by this forward bend is important in understanding the orientation of the uterus within the pelvic cavity. In most women, the uterus is anteflexed, meaning the body of the uterus is tilted forward over the cervix, and this occurs at the level of the internal os. Incorrect Responses: A. External os (A) The external os is the opening of the cervix into the vagina. The external os does not play a role in the angle of anteflexion, as the bend occurs at the internal os, not the external os. Thus, this option is incorrect. C. Cervix (C) The cervix is the lower part of the uterus, but the angle of anteflexion is not determined at the cervix itself. The cervix connects to the uterus at the internal os, where the angle of anteflexion occurs. Therefore, the cervix does not directly determine the angle. D. Isthmus (D) The isthmus is a region of the uterus between the cervix and the body. While it plays a role in uterine function and the shape of the uterus, the angle of anteflexion specifically occurs at the level of the internal os, not the isthmus. Therefore, this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: Which ligament carries ovarian artery in lateral wall:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Suspensory ligament of ovary. Correct Response: Suspensory ligament of ovary (B) The suspensory ligament of the ovary carries the ovarian artery in the lateral wall of the pelvis. This ligament extends from the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall, specifically attaching near the infundibulopelvic ligament. The ovarian artery, which arises from the abdominal aorta, passes through this ligament to supply blood to the ovaries. Therefore, the suspensory ligament of the ovary is the correct structure that carries the ovarian artery. Incorrect Responses: A. Ovarian ligament (A) The ovarian ligament connects the ovary to the lateral surface of the uterus. It does not carry the ovarian artery. While the ovarian ligament is involved in anchoring the ovary to the uterus, it does not transport the ovarian artery. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Broad ligament (C) The broad ligament is a large fold of peritoneum that helps support the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. While it is involved in holding the ovaries in place, it does not carry the ovarian artery. The broad ligament contains other structures, such as the round ligament and uterine vessels, but not the ovarian artery, which travels through the suspensory ligament of the ovary. Thus, this option is incorrect. D. Round ligament (D) The round ligament is responsible for holding the uterus in place by connecting the uterus to the labia majora. It does not carry the ovarian artery, which is found in the suspensory ligament of the ovary. The round ligament’s role is more related to the position of the uterus, not the ovarian vasculature,

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most susceptible to unintentional damage during hysterectomy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ureter. Correct Response: Ureter (B) The ureter is the most susceptible structure to unintentional damage during a hysterectomy. The ureters run close to the cervix and lateral walls of the uterus, and during the removal of the uterus, they can be inadvertently injured due to their proximity to the surgical field. The risk is particularly high when dissection is being performed in the lower abdomen and pelvic cavity, especially in cases of extensive adhesions or anatomical variations. Ureteral injury during hysterectomy can lead to serious complications like urinary leakage or even renal damage if not promptly recognized and repaired. Incorrect Responses: A. Uterine artery (A) The uterine artery is a major vessel that supplies the uterus, but it is generally well-identified and controlled during a hysterectomy. Although bleeding from the uterine artery can occur, it is usually preventable or manageable with careful ligation or cauterization during the procedure. Therefore, it is not as susceptible to unintentional damage as the ureter. C. Urinary bladder (C) The urinary bladder is also at risk during a hysterectomy, especially in cases of large uteri or when there is difficulty in separating the bladder from the uterus. However, damage to the bladder is less common compared to ureteral injury. Most of the bladder's risk arises from improper retraction or excessive dissection near the bladder dome. Despite this, the bladder is more easily recognized and repaired if injured compared to the ureter. D. Urethra (D) The urethra is anatomically situated in a way that it is relatively protected during a hysterectomy. While injury to the urethra is a possible complication, it is less commonly damaged than the ureter, as the urethra is positioned more anteriorly and away from the surgical dissection area. Urethral injury is typically less frequent compared to ureteral damage.

questions.text: All of the following are branches of uterine artery except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)Obturator artery.The obturator artery is not a branch of the uterine artery. It is a separate artery that originates from the internal iliac artery and supplies the medial compartment of the thigh, the hip joint, and the pelvic muscles. The obturator artery is anatomically distinct and does not have a direct relationship with the uterine artery, making it the correct exception in this case.Incorrect Responses:A. Spiral artery (A)The spiral arteries are important branches of the uterine artery. They play a crucial role in supplying blood to the endometrium, particularly during the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. The spiral arteries are responsible for providing oxygen and nutrients to the inner layers of the uterine lining, particularly in response to hormonal changes. Therefore, this option is incorrect because the spiral arteries are indeed branches of the uterine artery.B. Radial artery (B)The radial arteries are also branches of the uterine artery. They run along the myometrium and supply blood to the uterine muscle and the basal layer of the endometrium. They give rise to smaller arteries, including the spiral arteries, that supply the endometrial layer. This makes the radial arteries an essential branch of the uterine artery, so this option is incorrect.C. Basal artery (C)The basal arteries are branches of the uterine artery that supply the basal layer of the endometrium. They are part of the vascular network that ensures the uterine lining remains healthy and functional. The basal arteries are specifically important in the development and maintenance of the uterine lining, particularly during menstruation and implantation. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the basal artery is also a branch of the uterine artery.

choices.text: Where it is crossed by uterine artery
Where it is over obturator vessels

questions.text: M/C site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pelvic brim. Correct Response: Pelvic brim (A) The pelvic brim is the most common site of ureteric injury during a hysterectomy. As the ureter passes through the pelvis, it crosses the pelvic brim, which is the boundary between the abdominal and pelvic cavities. The proximity of the ureter to various structures, including blood vessels and the ovaries, makes it more vulnerable to injury during the procedure. Due to its location and the extent of dissection required near the pelvic brim during hysterectomy, this area presents the highest risk for ureteral damage. Incorrect Responses: B. Where it is crossed by uterine artery (B) The uterine artery crosses over the ureter in the parametrium, but this location is not as commonly involved in ureteral injury during hysterectomy as the pelvic brim. While the uterine artery is in close proximity to the ureter, surgeons are generally able to identify and manage the uterine artery, making injuries at this location less frequent compared to those occurring at the pelvic brim. C. Where it enters the bladder (C) The location where the ureter enters the bladder (the vesicoureteral junction) is less frequently injured during a hysterectomy. This area is generally well protected by the surrounding structures and is not directly involved in the surgical field when performing a hysterectomy, which reduces the risk of injury here. Thus, this option is less likely to be the most common site of injury. D. Where it is over obturator vessels (D) While the obturator vessels are close to the ureter, this location is not the most common site for injury during hysterectomy. The pelvic brim remains the most frequent area of concern due to the complexity and location of surgical dissection, making injuries over the obturator vessels relatively rare in comparison.

questions.text: All of the following support the uterus except.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Broad ligament. Correct Response: Broad ligament (C) The broad ligament does not primarily support the uterus in the same way as the other ligaments listed. The broad ligament is a large, flat sheet of peritoneum that supports the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. However, its role is more about providing a covering for these structures and containing vessels and nerves rather than directly supporting the uterus. The broad ligament helps maintain the position of the uterus in the pelvis, but it does not provide the same level of support as the other ligaments like the uterosacral, pubocervical, and cardinal ligaments, which are more directly involved in stabilizing the uterus. Incorrect Responses: A. Uterosacral ligament (A) The uterosacral ligament is a critical structure for supporting the uterus. It attaches the cervix and upper vagina to the sacrum. This ligament helps maintain the normal position of the uterus and prevents prolapse, providing significant support to the uterine cervix and the vagina. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Pubocervical ligament (B) The pubocervical ligament is also an important supportive structure for the uterus. It connects the cervix to the pubic bone and helps maintain the uterus in an anteverted and anteflexed position. This ligament is vital in providing support to the cervix and preventing uterine prolapse, making it an essential component of uterine support. Hence, this option is incorrect. D. Cardinal ligament (D) The cardinal ligament is one of the primary ligaments that support the uterus. It connects the cervix and the upper part of the vagina to the pelvic sidewall. The cardinal ligament is crucial in maintaining the position of the uterus and is often referred to as the "lateral support" of the uterus. This ligament helps prevent uterine prolapse and ensures the uterus stays in its proper position within the pelvic cavity. Thus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Canal of Nuck contains:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The canal of nuck is an abnomal patent pouch of peritoneum extending into the labia majora of women. It is analogous to patent processces vaginalis in males. It is attached to the uterus by the round ligament through the internal inguinal ring into the inguinal canal. Normally it obliterates and disappears by 1st year of life.

questions.text: The ligament which helps to keep the uterus in anteverted and anteflexed position:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The round ligament of the uterus originates at the uterine horns, in the parametrium. The round ligament exits the pelvis via the deep inguinal ring. It passes through the inguinal canal to reach the labium majus,inserting into the fibro-fatty substance of the labium majus. The round ligament of uterus acts to hold the uterus anterior-ward to in anteflexion and anteversion, especially by counteracting any posterior-ward forces that may be being exerted upon the uterus (e.g. distended bladder, or gravity while in a recumbent postition)

questions.text: The ligament which prevents retroversion of uterus:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The uterosacral ligaments pull the cervix posterior-ward, counteracting the anterior-ward pull exerted by the round ligament of uterus upon the fundus of the uterus, thus maintaining anteversion of the body of the uterus.

questions.text: Which of the following is formed by Mullerian duct in males?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hydatid of Morgagni. Correct Response: Hydatid of Morgagni (B) The hydatid of Morgagni is a remnant of the Müllerian duct in males. During embryonic development, both males and females initially have Müllerian ducts, which can develop into female reproductive structures (such as the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper vagina). In males, however, these ducts typically regress due to the influence of anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) secreted by the testes. A small remnant of the Müllerian duct can persist as the hydatid of Morgagni, which is a small cystic structure located on the epididymis. Therefore, the hydatid of Morgagni is the correct answer as it is formed by the Müllerian duct in males. Incorrect Responses: A. Testis (A) The testis is not formed by the Müllerian duct but instead develops from the gonadal ridge, which is a separate structure. The testes are formed from the mesodermal tissue and differentiate under the influence of the Y chromosome, particularly the SRY gene, which leads to the formation of male reproductive organs. The testes are part of the male reproductive system but are not derived from the Müllerian duct. Hence, this option is incorrect. C. Seminal vesicle (C) The seminal vesicle is formed from the Wolffian duct (also known as the mesonephric duct) in males, not from the Müllerian duct. The Wolffian duct develops into several male reproductive structures, including the seminal vesicles, epididymis, and vas deferens. The Müllerian ducts, on the other hand, typically regress in males. Therefore, this option is incorrect. D. Epoophoron (D) The epoophoron is a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct) in females, not the Müllerian duct. It is a small group of tubules that can be found in the broad ligament of the uterus. In males, remnants of the mesonephric duct may form structures like the epididymis or vas deferens. Hence, the epoophoron is not formed by the Müllerian duct and is an incorrect answer.

questions.text: The target gene for SRY which favors testis differentiation is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) SOX-9 gene. Correct Response: SOX-9 gene (A) The SOX-9 gene is the target gene for the SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene that promotes testis differentiation. The SRY gene, located on the Y chromosome, is critical for initiating male sex determination. When the SRY gene is expressed, it activates the transcription of the SOX-9 gene, which in turn stimulates the development of the testes from the undifferentiated gonads. SOX-9 plays a pivotal role in the differentiation of Sertoli cells and the formation of testicular structures. Therefore, the SOX-9 gene is the correct answer, as it is directly involved in the process of testis differentiation initiated by SRY. Incorrect Responses: B. RSPO1 gene (B) The RSPO1 gene is involved in ovarian development, not testis differentiation. RSPO1 plays a role in the activation of the WNT signaling pathway, which supports ovarian differentiation. It is not a target of the SRY gene in the context of male sex determination. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. DAX1 gene (C) The DAX1 gene is associated with female development and acts as an antagonist to the SRY gene. DAX1 is involved in ovarian development and, when overexpressed, can inhibit the action of SRY and promote female characteristics. It is not a target of the SRY gene but rather plays a role in counteracting male differentiation. Hence, this option is incorrect. D. WNT-4 gene (D) The WNT-4 gene is another gene involved in female differentiation. It is part of the signaling pathways that promote ovarian development. WNT-4 is not regulated by the SRY gene, and its expression is part of the process leading to the formation of female gonads. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Vertical fusion defect can result in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Transverse vaginal septum. Correct Response: Transverse vaginal septum (D) A vertical fusion defect during embryonic development occurs when there is an incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to the formation of a transverse vaginal septum. This septum is a fibrous or muscular barrier that can block the vagina at various levels, leading to obstructed menstruation and other reproductive issues. The transverse vaginal septum forms as a result of improper fusion along the vertical axis of the Müllerian ducts. Therefore, this is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Septate uterus (A) A septate uterus is caused by a horizontal fusion defect, where the two Müllerian ducts fail to fuse properly at the midline, leaving a fibrous or muscular septum in the uterus. This is a common congenital uterine anomaly but does not result from a vertical fusion defect. Hence, this option is incorrect. B. Didelphic uterus (B) A didelphic uterus occurs when there is complete failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts, resulting in two distinct uterine cavities, two cervices, and sometimes two vaginas. This anomaly results from a complete horizontal fusion defect, not a vertical one. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Bicornuate uterus (C) A bicornuate uterus results from a partial failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts. It is a horizontal fusion defect that causes a heart-shaped uterus with two horns. While this defect involves a horizontal fusion issue, it does not arise from a vertical fusion defect, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: M/C uterine malformation associated with renal anomalies:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Unicornuate. Correct Response: Unicornuate uterus (B) A unicornuate uterus is the most common uterine malformation associated with renal anomalies. This occurs when one of the Müllerian ducts fails to develop completely during embryonic life, leading to the formation of a single uterine horn. Additionally, renal anomalies, such as renal agenesis (the absence of a kidney), are frequently seen with unicornuate uterus. The condition arises from a complete failure of development of one of the Müllerian ducts and is often associated with a variety of renal malformations, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Bicornuate uterus (A) A bicornuate uterus is a congenital uterine malformation caused by partial failure of the fusion of the Müllerian ducts. While it is a significant uterine anomaly, it is less commonly associated with renal anomalies compared to the unicornuate uterus. Therefore, this option is incorrect in the context of being the most common uterine malformation associated with renal anomalies. C. Septate uterus (C) A septate uterus results from incomplete resorption of the septum between the two Müllerian ducts. It is a common uterine anomaly but is not as strongly associated with renal anomalies as the unicornuate uterus. Septate uterus is more often seen as an isolated anomaly, and renal anomalies are less frequently observed with this condition. Therefore, this option is incorrect. D. Didelphys (D) A didelphys uterus occurs when there is a complete failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts, resulting in two distinct uterine cavities, two cervices, and sometimes two vaginas. While didelphys can be associated with other abnormalities, it is not the most common uterine malformation linked to renal anomalies. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: M/C uterine malformation associated with infertility
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Septate. Correct Response: Septate uterus (C) A septate uterus is the most common uterine malformation associated with infertility. It occurs due to incomplete resorption of the uterine septum, leaving a partition in the uterus. This condition can interfere with implantation, leading to recurrent miscarriages or difficulty achieving pregnancy. The septum can distort the uterine cavity, reducing the chances of successful pregnancy and contributing to infertility. As it is one of the most common causes of infertility related to structural uterine anomalies, septate uterus is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Bicornuate uterus (A) A bicornuate uterus results from partial failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts. While it can cause complications during pregnancy, such as preterm labor or malpresentation, it is less frequently associated with infertility compared to a septate uterus. The presence of two uterine horns may not always interfere with the ability to conceive. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Unicornuate uterus (B) A unicornuate uterus occurs when one of the Müllerian ducts fails to develop fully, leading to a single uterine horn. While it can be associated with infertility and higher rates of miscarriage, it is less common than the septate uterus in terms of infertility-related malformations. Furthermore, it is more often associated with severe renal anomalies, making this option incorrect. D. Didelphys (D) A didelphys uterus results from complete failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to two distinct uterine cavities. This condition typically does not cause infertility, although it can be associated with pregnancy complications such as preterm labor. Since didelphys is less likely to directly cause infertility than the septate uterus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Diethylstilbestrol causes the following defects except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diethylstilbestrol exposure in utero leads to varied anomalies of female genital tract. “Unlike all other congenital uterine malformations, the DES uterus is not associated with an increase in renal anomalies” In males it leads to- hypospadias cryptorchidism, testcular hypoplasia. Other important points : Uterine anomalies = MIC : Hypoplastic uterus Most characteristic = T shaped uterine cavity In males it leads to Hypospadias Cryptorchidism Testicular hypoplasia

questions.text: Exposure of a female fetus to androgen in early V embryogenesis may arrest differentiation of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Urogenital sinus. Correct Response: Urogenital sinus (C) Exposure of a female fetus to androgens during early embryogenesis can disrupt the differentiation of the urogenital sinus, which normally develops into the lower part of the female reproductive system, including the vagina and urethra. Androgens, such as testosterone, can cause masculinization of the female fetus, leading to a failure in the normal differentiation of the urogenital sinus. This results in conditions such as a vaginal atresia or urogenital abnormalities. Therefore, urethra and vagina differentiation are affected by androgen exposure, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. Müllerian ducts (A) The Müllerian ducts typically differentiate into the female reproductive organs (uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper two-thirds of the vagina). However, androgens mainly influence the Wolffian ducts (mesonephric ducts) and do not directly arrest the differentiation of the Müllerian ducts in females. In fact, Müllerian ducts are generally not affected by androgens unless there is a mutation in the Müllerian-inhibiting substance or hormone. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Ovary (B) The ovary develops from the gonadal ridge in the absence of male hormones. Androgens do not directly arrest ovarian differentiation; however, excessive androgen exposure can lead to virilization but does not prevent the development of ovaries. The presence of androgens might affect the function of the ovaries or cause abnormalities in secondary sexual characteristics, but they do not stop the formation of ovaries themselves. Hence, this option is incorrect. D. Mesonephric ducts (D) The mesonephric ducts (also called the Wolffian ducts) are primarily involved in the development of male reproductive structures, such as the epididymis, vas deferens, and seminal vesicles, in the presence of testosterone. In females, these ducts regress due to the absence of androgens. Androgen exposure typically does not interfere with the normal regression of the Wolffian ducts in females.

questions.text: SRY region is present on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The gene SRY (sex determining region of the Y), located at the distal region of the short arm of the Y chromosome, is necessary for male sex determination in mammals. SRY initiates the cascade of steps necessary to form a testis from an undifferentiated gonad. The SRY gene encodes an HMG (High Mobility Group) protein which may act as a transcription factor by binding to double stranded DNA and then bending the DNA. Mutations in SRY have been identified in some subjects with 46,XY pure gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: On digital examination of the apical region of the vagina, the structure presented first to the examining finger is the posterior lip of the cervix. This observation rules out which of the following uterine postures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anteversion • The normal posture of the uterus is anteverted and antefiexed. • If the anterior lip of the cervix is palpated first during vaginal examination, the cervix is in an anteverted position. • If the cervix is retroverted, either the cervical os or the posterior lip of the cervix is the first structure to be palpated.

questions.text: A 35-years-old woman with severe dysmenorhea and prolonged menstrual periods due to large uterine fibroids undergoes a hysterectomy. Which of the following structures is the gynecologist most likely to inadvertently-ligate during surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer D The ureter passes directly inferior to the uterine artery, lateral to the body of the uterus near its junction with the cervix ("water ?ows under the bridge"). During a hysterectomy, therefore, the ureter (instead of the uterine artery) may be inadvertently ligated.

questions.text: Match the columns with relevant embryologically correct statements
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Epoophoron is the cranial remnant of mesonephric tubules in females while paroophoron is caudal remnant of mesonephric tubules. Gartners is cranial remnant of mesonephric duct and all the three remnants are present in the broad ligament I females . Genital tubercle in females forms the clitoris while in males it forms the penis. Appendix of testes also called as hydatid of Morgagni is remnant of paramesonephric ducts Ovary is derived from genital ridge at around 8 weeks

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is seen for evaluation of a swelling in the right, posterior aspect of her vaginal opening. She has noted pain in this area when walking and during coitus. At the time of pelvic examination the cyst is noted at 7 oclock position. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Although rare, adenocarcinoma of the Bartholin gland must be excluded in women more than 40 years of age who present with a cystic or solid mass in this area. The incidence peaks in women in their sixes. The appropriate treatment in these cases is surgical excision of the Bartholin gland to allow for a careful pathologic examination. In cases of abscess formation, both marsupializaon of the sac and incision with drainage as well as appropriate antibiotics are accepted modes of therapy. In the case of the asymptomatic Bartholin cyst, no treatment is necessary.

choices.text: A is round ligament b is Fallopian tube c is ovarian lig
C is round, a is Fallopian tube b is ovarian ligament
A is Fallopian tube, b is round C is ovarian
C is Fallopian tube, b is ovarian Ligament and a is round lig

questions.text: Identify A,B and C correctly
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A is Fallopian tube, B is round ligament, C is ovarian ligament. Correct Response: A is Fallopian tube, B is round ligament, C is ovarian ligament (C) The Fallopian tube is located near the uterus and connects to the ovary, making it the most proximal structure to the uterus, which is A in the given question. The round ligament connects the uterus to the labia majora and is found running anteriorly from the uterus to the inguinal canal, so it is B. Finally, the ovarian ligament connects the ovary to the uterus and is positioned near the ovary, making it C. This arrangement is accurate according to the anatomy of the female reproductive system. Therefore, C is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: A. A is round ligament, B is Fallopian tube, C is ovarian ligament (A) This option places the round ligament as A, but the round ligament is not positioned near the uterus in the way described in the question. The Fallopian tube is a more fitting structure for B, and the ovarian ligament is typically closer to the ovary, which is correctly identified as C. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. C is round ligament, A is Fallopian tube, B is ovarian ligament (B) This option incorrectly identifies C as the round ligament and B as the ovarian ligament. The round ligament and ovarian ligament should be swapped in this case. The Fallopian tube should still be A, but the placement of B and C is incorrect in this arrangement. Hence, this option is incorrect. D. C is Fallopian tube, B is ovarian ligament, A is round ligament (D) This option reverses the positions of the Fallopian tube and round ligament, which would cause confusion in identifying the structures. The round ligament should be in B, while the Fallopian tube is best placed as A in the female reproductive system.

questions.text: Injury to this muscle of the pelvic floor (shown in green) leads to prolapse of uterus and cervix
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) LEVATOR ANI muscle is made of the following components –pubococcygeus, puborectalis and iliococcygeus. Ischiococcygeus is not a component of levator ani muscle Injury to puborectalis and pubococcygeus during difficult labor and instrumental delivery can lead to prolapse of uterus and cervix and may also produce urinary symptoms The nerve supply to levator ani is pudendal nerve through nerve segments S2 S3 and direct fibres of S4.
